Posted By: Khias (1/29/2010 11:43:06 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
This card is pretty nuts. Wizards apparently really wants Vampires to become a Deck-to-beat, huh?  
It's a 2/2 two-drop by itself.  
The trigger is a [Vampiric Touch](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vampiric Touch) for just a single black mana instead of ![2](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=2&type=symbol)![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol).  
*(Or a [Syphon Soul](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Syphon Soul) to name the more known version, yet the other one suits better for two reasons)*.  
This means each time one of your Vampires dies, the difference between your and your opponent's life total will increase by four if you can afford to pay ![Black](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=B&type=symbol).  
Sounds pretty insane, especially when realizing that club Vampire also includes [Bloodghast](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodghast), who will return with each land.  
  
Regarding flavor she is also pretty nuts - boasting with [Mindless Null](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mindless Null)s? Now that's the last thing a Magic player would do.
posts.html:
This card is pretty nuts. Wizards apparently really wants Vampires to become a Deck-to-beat, huh?
It's a 2/2 two-drop by itself.
The trigger is a Vampiric Touch for just a single black mana instead of .
(Or a Syphon Soul to name the more known version, yet the other one suits better for two reasons).
This means each time one of your Vampires dies, the difference between your and your opponent's life total will increase by four if you can afford to pay .
Sounds pretty insane, especially when realizing that club Vampire also includes Bloodghast, who will return with each land.

Regarding flavor she is also pretty nuts - boasting with Mindless Nulls? Now that's the last thing a Magic player would do.

Posted By: CatsAreCthala (1/31/2010 8:20:39 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I find the art terribly misleading.  
It appears more like it should function along the lines of [Rotlung Reanimator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Rotlung Reanimator). (how awesome would that be?)  
  
That being said, this isn't nearly the powerhouse some make it out to be.  
Yes, its very powerful, but most competitively viable vampire decks tend to tap out alot.  
  
She lends herself better to slower control decks over the aggro route typically taken.
posts.html:

Posted By: Relix (2/3/2010 5:13:10 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Especially good if you have a way to sac. vamps every turn. Especially good with [Kalitas, Bloodchief of Ghet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kalitas, Bloodchief of Ghet) and/or [Crovax the Cursed](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Crovax the Cursed). With Kalitas, you're sacing vamps to get vamp tokens with the same power and toughness. Which is useful with vamps who have no useful abilities once they're on the battlefield ([Gatekeeper of Malakir](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gatekeeper of Malakir), I'm looking at you), vamps who have drawback effects ([Vampire Lacerator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Vampire Lacerator)), or ones who are about to die anyway. Combo Kalitas with [Bloodghast](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bloodghast) and your combo gets super-deadly. With Crovax, you're pumping him in addition to hurting your opponent. Only problem with him is you have to sac a creature each turn or he loses some power.
  
   
So basically, your opponent's gonna be in pain no matter what strategy you use....
  
   
Alright, I'm off to make a vamp deck.
